The Museum of the Jewish History (MoH) in New York is planning to close its doors permanently in April 2020 in order to focus on a multimillion-dollar redevelopment that will include the construction of a new museum.The announcement follows a two-year period of “exploring new ways to engage with contemporary Jewish history and culture,” said curator David K. Shapiro, who was appointed MoH’s director in February. The institution will also expand its collection by adding more than two hundred works to its collection by women artists, and it will host more programming.The institution, which has been in operation since 1912 and consists of three buildings that were completed in 1967 and 1971, has faced many setbacks in its redevelopment. In 2010, MoH director Daniel H. Weiss revealed that the redevelopment project would “aim for a certain degree of sustainability,” but said that the museum would have to continue to operate under certain conditions, such as without visitors.
